user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DeleteAllObjects:
```c
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_DeleteAllObjects:
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB 0x09
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK 0x01
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 1.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment does not use any compiler-specific language extensions. Constructs like while(true) rely on the standard boolean macro (true) from <stdbool.h> or a project-defined macro, and the other identifiers (uint32 typedef and #define constants) are standard C or project headers, not compiler extensions.
